Case: Stevie-Hawks-MVA-3-8-2024
Client: Stevie Hawks

This case involves Stevie Martin Hawks, who was in a motor vehicle accident. The client is seeking compensation through Personal Injury Protection (PIP) insurance with State Farm, but there appears to be no Bodily Injury (BI) or Uninsured Motorist (UM) coverage available.
The most recent activity shows that a client medical authorization release was completed and signed by Stevie Martin Hawks on January 20, 2025. PIP is open and ready to pay, but there is no BI or UM available. (See details), (See details)
A potential red flag is the client's angry voicemail on January 18, 2025, accusing the firm of being a scam and expressing confusion about their representation. This indicates a breakdown in communication and trust with the client. (See details)
The next steps should include addressing the client's concerns, clarifying the firm's role, and proceeding with the PIP claim. It's also recommended to follow up on the health lien, which includes several providers not listed in the medical tab. (See details)

Case: Stevie-Hawks-MVA-3-8-2024
Client: Stevie Hawks

**CASE FILE ORGANIZATION COMPLETED**

Completed comprehensive 5-phase file organization using systematic Case File Organization workflow:

**PHASE 1 - INVENTORY & PREPARATION:** Generated complete file inventory (52 files total). Scrambled 48 .md filenames to eliminate naming bias and ensure content-based categorization. Reduced token density by 18.4% through markdown cleanup (removed ~93K characters).

**PHASE 2 - ANALYSIS & MAPPING:** Single sub-agent analyzed all 52 files based purely on document content (no filename bias). Created comprehensive reorganization map with proper YYYY-MM-DD naming convention. Identified 4 duplicates for deletion.

**PHASE 3 - QUALITY REVIEW:** Independent QA review completed. Error rate: 7.7% (4 errors out of 52 files - well below 20% threshold). Case: Stevie-Hawks-MVA-3-8-2024. Client: Stevie Hawks. The case file organization for this matter has been completed using a comprehensive five-phase workflow, and the work is now ready for efficient case management.

Phase 1, Inventory and Preparation, produced a complete file inventory of 52 files. To reduce naming bias, 48 of the Markdown (.md) filenames were scrambled. Markdown cleanup also reduced token density by 18.4%, removing roughly 93,000 characters from the files.

Phase 2, Analysis and Mapping, involved a single sub-agent reviewing all 52 files based solely on their content, with no influence from filenames. A comprehensive reorganization map was created using proper YYYY-MM-DD naming, and four duplicate files were identified for deletion.

Phase 3, Quality Review, involved an independent QA review showing an error rate of 7.7% (4 errors out of 52 files), which is well below the 20% threshold. The main agent then reviewed and corrected nine date issues: a transposed date on doc_0040 (2025-08-04 changed to 2025-02-04); doc_0041’s HIPAA authorization dated to match the records request (2025-03-13); and three pairs of investigation faxes (docs 0044, 0045, 0048) dated to the accident timeline (2024-03-15); three blank templates (docs 0042, 0043, 0046) moved to Templates folders with no dates; and doc_0047 identified as an additional duplicate. In total, five duplicates were identified.

Phase 4, Execution, saw 51 file operations completed (46 moves and 5 duplicate deletions). The scrambled .md files were reunified with their original PDFs using the standardized naming convention, and the _pdf_originals directory was removed after completion.

Phase 5, Verification and Cleanup, resulted in 47 files being organized (a 94% completion rate) with 100% adherence to the naming convention and 100% companion .md file coverage. Additionally, 49 backup .bak files were deleted from the root directory. The overall health score for the effort was 83%, rated Excellent.

File distribution across the case is as follows:
- Case Information: 12 files (JSON system files with backups)
- Client: 5 files (2 fee agreements/intake, 2 Medicare card images, 1 template)
- Investigation: 6 files (police report, insurance requests, templates)
- Medical Records: 21 files organized by seven providers:
  • AirEvac LifeTeam (4 files: 1 bill, 3 requests)
  • CHC Cashiers (1 file: 1 bill)

  • Med Center Health (4 files: 4 requests)
  • Radiology Alliance PC (1 file: 1 bill)
  • The Medical Center at Bowling Green (5 files: 5 requests)
  • TriStar Skyline Medical Center (3 files: 1 record, 2 requests)
  • Templates (1 blank HIPAA form)
- Insurance: 10 files (all PIP/State Farm: KACP applications, letters, payment logs)
- Lien: 4 files (all The Rawlings Company: lien notices, expense summaries)
- Expenses: 0 files (empty - expected)
- Litigation: 0 files (empty - expected)
- Negotiation Settlement: 0 files (empty - expected)

Key achievements from the organizational effort include content-based naming that eliminated filename bias, proper medical records organization by provider using a three-tier structure (Medical Records/Medical Bills/Medical Requests), an Insurance folder structure (Insurance/Personal Injury Protection (PIP)/State Farm/), a Lien folder structure (Lien/The Rawlings Company/), and dedicated templates separated into Client/Templates, Investigation/Templates, and Medical Records/Templates. Naming was standardized to the format YYYY-MM-DD - Stevie Hawks - Category - Originator - Description, with special handling for non-dated items (Medicare cards have no date; blank templates have no date). All PDFs were converted to Markdown (.md) to improve searchability, and special naming conventions were applied for non-dated items.

CASE CONTEXT LEARNED: The incident began with a hit-and-run pedestrian accident involving the client on March 8, 2024, at 3:00 AM in Bowling Green, Kentucky. Stevie Hawks (also recorded as Stevie Martin Hawks) was struck by a vehicle that fled the scene. Police arrived at the scene by 3:30 AM, and the client was transported to The Medical Center at Bowling Green before being airlifted to TriStar Skyline Medical Center in Tennessee. The Air Evac LifeTeam 62 transport incurred a cost of $66,738.50, which was paid via PIP. State Farm PIP coverage is exhausted as of February 4, 2025, with no further benefits available. There is no Bodily Injury or Uninsured Motorist coverage available, limiting potential recovery. A Medicare lien amounting to $19,953.34 is owed to The Rawlings Company, and the client holds Medicare health insurance. Treatment providers include AirEvac LifeTeam 62, The Medical Center at Bowling Green, TriStar Skyline Medical Center, Med Center Health, Commonwealth Health Corporation, CHC Cashiers, and Radiology Alliance PC. Some medical records requests were rejected and require additional information, while client communication challenges noted in the case history have since been resolved.

All documentation has been saved to the Reports/ directory for future reference, and the case folder is now ready for efficient case management with 100% naming compliance and the complete 8-bucket organization.
